questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique

options.label: B
options.text: The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm

options.label: C
options.text: It has a life-span of 5 years

options.label: D
options.text: It is used in emergency contraception

questions.correct_answer: C. It has a life-span of 5 years
questions.explanation:
2nd generation IUDs

Type

Copper containing device

Mechanism of action
  • Reduces sperm motility and survival
    • alters cervical mucus
    • affects uterine enzymes
    • increases cellular response in endometrium

Features
  • Strong anti-fertility effect
  • Low expulsion rate
  • Easy to fit in nulliparous women
  • Lesser side effects
  • Effective post-coital contraceptive (Option D ruled out)

Side effects
  • Bleeding
  • Pain
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine perforation
  • Failure of contraception ➜ Pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion
  • Migration of IUD

Insertion technique

Withdrawl technique (Option A ruled out)

CuT 380A
  • 380 mm² of copper wire around a stem with nylon thread attached (Option B ruled out)
  • Shelf life -10 years (Option C)

Nova-T
  • CuT 380 A with a silver (Ag) core attached to it
  • Shelf life - 5 years

Multiload
  • U-shaped ring
  • Most commonly used IUD
  • CuT 375

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the scope of modern family planning services?

options.label: B
options.text: Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother

options.label: C
options.text: MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case

options.label: D
options.text: MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: C. MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in th

questions.text: A couple approaches the doctor with a query regarding sexual precautions following the male partner's vasectomy procedure conducted a month ago. What guidance should be provided in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman

options.label: D
options.text: Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.text: What is the most frequent side effect experienced by a 24-year-old woman of reproductive age who visited a rural primary healthcare center in India for the purpose of having an IUCD inserted to prevent pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding (Option D)
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain (Option C ruled out)

Frequently causes removal; managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (OptionB ruled out)

Certain organisms reach the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries via the IUD thread. Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Higher risk in women with multiple sexual partners. Requires broad-spectrum antibiotics; IUD removal if no improvement.

Uterine perforation

Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of pregnancy.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications
    • Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.

Ectopic pregnancy (OPTION A ruled out)

Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion

Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation; higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD

Rarely causes intestinal obstruction; diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is using vaginal sponge as a barrier contraceptive during sexual intercourse. Which of the following Spermicide is used in contraceptive 'TODAY'?
questions.explanation:
Brand name

TODAY

Material

Small polyurethane foam sponge

Mechanism of action

Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ (Option C)

Technique of use
  • Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion
  • Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective
  • Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation
  • All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today)

Disadvantages
  • No protection from HIV or STDs
  • May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours
  • Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation
  • Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI
  • Higher failure rate than diaphragm

Failure rate
  • Parous women: 20-40 per HWY
  • Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

questions.text: Which type of cancer won't be affected if a patient uses OCP, which is a protective factor for?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A: E

Chemical Contraceptive

How It Works

Advantages

Disadvantages

Nonoxynol-9

Disrupts sperm membranes, immobilizing or killing sperm
  • Readily available and affordable
  • May cause irritation or allergic reactions

Contraceptive Sponge

Contains spermicide that immobilizes or kills sperm
  • Convenient and non-hormonal
  • Less effective than some other contraceptive methods

Spermicidal Cream/Gel

Contains chemicals that immobilize or kill sperm
  • Non-hormonal and can be used on-demand
  • May cause irritation or allergic reactions

Vaginal Suppositories

Release spermicidal chemicals into the vagina
  • Easy to use and can be inserted discreetly
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse

Vaginal Film

Dissolves and releases spermicidal chemicals in the vagina
  • Convenient and can be used on-demand
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse

Vaginal Foam

Creates a foam that immobilizes or kills sperm
  • Easy to use and provides localized application
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse
  • May cause irritation or discomfort

options.text: Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

questions.text: Which contraceptive method should not be used in cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.explanation:
Contraceptive Method

Contraindications

Combined Oral Contraceptives

(COCs)

 

 

 

 

 

 
  • History of blood clots, stroke, or heart disease
  • Liver disease or tumors
  • Breast cancer
  • Severe hypertension (high blood pressure)
  • Migraine with aura
  • Current or history of certain types of cancer, such as liver, cervical, or uterine cancer
  • Smokers over the age of 35
  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • History of gallbladder disease

Progestin-Only Pills (POPs)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
  • Current or history of breast cancer
  • Liver disease or tumors
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Severe hypertension (high blood pressure)
  • Migraine with aura
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Active liver disease
  • Severe liver dysfunction
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy

Contraceptive Patch

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
  • History of blood clots, stroke, or heart disease
  • Liver disease or tumors
  • Breast cancer
  • Uncontrolled hypertension (high blood pressure)
  • Migraine with aura
  • History of certain types of cancer, such as liver, cervical, or uterine cancer
  • Smokers over the age of 35
  • Obesity (BMI ≥ 30)
  • Age over 35 and heavy smoking (15 or more cigarettes per day)

Contraceptive Implants

 

 

 

 
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Active liver disease
  • Liver tumors
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Breast cancer
  • Hypersensitivity to the implant components
Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)

 

 

 

 

 

 
  • Current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or history of recurrent PID
  • Current or recent (within the past 3 months) pelvic infection
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine abnormalities
  • Active cervical, uterine, or ovarian cancer
  • Wilson's disease
  • Copper allergy (for copper IUD)

Barrier Methods
  • None

questions.text: What are the absolute contraindications for intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs)?
questions.explanation:
Absolute Relative 
Pregnancy Anemia, Menorrhagia 
Recurrent PID History of PID 
Vaginal discharge of undiagnosed etiology  Purulent cervical discharge 
Cancer of cervix, uterus or adnexa  Distortion of uterine cavities e.g., congenital malformations, fibroids 
Previous ectopic pregnancy  Unmotivated person 

Contraceptive Method

Contraindications

Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)

 

 

 

 

 

 
  • Current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or history of recurrent PID
  • Current or recent (within the past 3 months) pelvic infection
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine abnormalities
  • Active cervical, uterine, or ovarian cancer
  • Wilson's disease
  • Copper allergy (for copper IUD)

questions.text: The most suitable contraceptive recommendation for a recently married couple is:
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ When providing contraceptive advice to a newly married couple, several factors need to be considered, including effectiveness, convenience, safety, and personal preferences. While the choice ultimately depends on the couple's specific needs and circumstances, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are often a suitable option for many couples.
  • ↳ OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills): OCPs are a highly effective form of contraception when used correctly. They provide reliable pregnancy prevention, are convenient to use, and have additional benefits such as regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual pain, and improving acne. OCPs can be started immediately and discontinued when the couple decides to conceive.
  • ↳ OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills):
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception that provide protection against both unintended pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are easily accessible, affordable, and do not require a prescription. Condoms can be a good option for couples who prefer non-hormonal methods or need STI protection in addition to contraception. However, they may have a higher failure rate compared to hormonal methods like OCPs.
  • ↳ Option B: Condoms:
  • ↳ Option C: Sterilization: Sterilization, such as tubal ligation for women or vasectomy for men, is a permanent method of contraception. It is considered a long-term and highly effective option for couples who have completed their desired family size or do not wish to have biological children. Sterilization should be approached as a permanent decision, as reversal procedures are costly and not always successful.
  • ↳ Option C: Sterilization:
  • ↳ Option D: IUD (Intrauterine Device): IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives that offer highly effective contraception for an extended period. They can be a suitable choice for couples who desire long-term contraception without the need for daily or frequent user involvement. However, IUDs require a healthcare provider's insertion, which may not be immediately accessible for a newly married couple.
  • ↳ Option D: IUD (Intrauterine Device):
    • References:

    • ↳ Importance of Family Planning: Newly married couples may have different aspirations and plans for their future. Family planning through contraception enables them to establish a strong foundation in their marriage, pursue education or career goals, and ensure emotional and financial stability before starting a family.
    • ↳ Choice of Contraceptive Methods: There are various contraceptive methods available for newly wedded couples. The choice of method depends on factors such as effectiveness, convenience, personal preferences, health conditions, and future pregnancy plans. Some commonly used methods include: a. Barrier Methods: These include male and female condoms, diaphragms, and cervical caps. They provide a physical barrier to prevent sperm from reaching the egg. b. Hormonal Methods: These include combined oral contraceptives (COCs), progestin-only pills (POPs), contraceptive patches, injections, implants, and hormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs). They work by altering hormone levels to inhibit ovulation, thinning the uterine lining, and thickening cervical mucus. c. Intrauterine Devices (IUDs): These small, T-shaped devices are inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy. They can be hormonal (releasing progestin) or non-hormonal (copper-based) and provide long-term contraception. d. Sterilization: Permanent methods like tubal ligation (for women) or vasectomy (for men) can be considered if the couple has completed their desired family size.
    • ↳ Counseling and Education: Newly wedded couples should receive comprehensive counseling on different contraceptive methods. They should understand the benefits, effectiveness, possible side effects, and proper usage of each method. Couples should also be aware of emergency contraception options in case of contraceptive failure or unprotected intercourse.
    • ↳ Dual Protection: Newly wedded couples may also consider using dual protection by combining two methods, such as using condoms along with hormonal contraceptives. This provides added protection against unintended pregnancies and reduces the risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
    • ↳ Regular Follow-up and Reassessment: Couples should have regular follow-up visits with a healthcare provider to assess the effectiveness of the chosen contraceptive method and address any concerns or side effects. As their needs may change over time, periodic reassessment of the contraceptive method may be necessary.
    • ↳ Communication and Shared Decision-Making: It is important for newly wedded couples to openly communicate about their contraception preferences, concerns, and future plans. Shared decision-making ensures that both partners are actively involved in choosing the most suitable contraceptive method for their unique circumstances.

questions.text: What should be the minimum rate of couple protection in order to achieve the demographic target of NRR = 1? NRR: Net Reproduction Rate
questions.explanation: Correct Option D: 60%

questions.text: Which contraceptive method has the highest reported failure rate?
questions.explanation:
Contraceptive Method

Typical Failure Rate

Barrier Methods

 

- Male Condom

13% (with typical use)

- Female Condom

21% (with typical use)

Hormonal Methods

 

- Combined Oral Contraceptives

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

- Progestin-Only Pills

5% (with typical use)

- Injectable Contraceptives

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

- Implant

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)

 

- Copper IUD

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

- Hormonal IUD

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

Permanent Methods

 

- Tubal Ligation

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

- Vasectomy

Less than 1% (with perfect use)

Emergency Contraception

 

- Emergency Contraceptive Pill

1-2% (with typical use)

- Copper IUD as Emergency Contraception

Less than 1% (with perfect use)
